text: Many have undertaken to draw up an account of the things that have been fulfilled among us,
speaker: Narrator

text: just as they were handed down to us by those who from the first were eyewitnesses and servants of the word.
speaker: Narrator

text: With this in mind, since I myself have carefully investigated everything from the beginning, I too decided to write an orderly account for you, most excellent Theophilus,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you may know the certainty of the things you have been taught.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the time of Herod king of Judea there was a priest named Zechariah, who belonged to the priestly division of Abijah; his wife Elizabeth was also a descendant of Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both of them were righteous in the sight of God, observing all the Lord’s commands and decrees blamelessly.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were childless because Elizabeth was not able to conceive, and they were both very old.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when Zechariah’s division was on duty and he was serving as priest before God,
speaker: Narrator

text: he was chosen by lot, according to the custom of the priesthood, to go into the temple of the Lord and burn incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the time for the burning of incense came, all the assembled worshipers were praying outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing at the right side of the altar of incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zechariah saw him, he was startled and was gripped with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel said to him: “Do not be afraid, Zechariah; your prayer has been heard. Your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you are to call him John.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be a joy and delight to you, and many will rejoice because of his birth,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he will be great in the sight of the Lord. He is never to take wine or other fermented drink, and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit even before he is born.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will bring back many of the people of Israel to the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he will go on before the Lord, in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of the parents to their children and the disobedient to the wisdom of the righteous—to make ready a people prepared for the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah asked the angel, “How can I be sure of this? I am an old man and my wife is well along in years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel said to him, “I am Gabriel. I stand in the presence of God, and I have been sent to speak to you and to tell you this good news.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now you will be silent and not able to speak until the day this happens, because you did not believe my words, which will come true at their appointed time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the people were waiting for Zechariah and wondering why he stayed so long in the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came out, he could not speak to them. They realized he had seen a vision in the temple, for he kept making signs to them but remained unable to speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his time of service was completed, he returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this his wife Elizabeth became pregnant and for five months remained in seclusion.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord has done this for me,” she said. “In these days he has shown his favor and taken away my disgrace among the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a town in Galilee,
speaker: Narrator

text: to a virgin pledged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of David. The virgin’s name was Mary.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel went to her and said, “Greetings, you who are highly favored! The Lord is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Mary was greatly troubled at his words and wondered what kind of greeting this might be.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel said to her, “Do not be afraid, Mary; you have found favor with God.
speaker: Jesus

text: You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you are to call him Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his father David,
speaker: Jesus

text: and he will reign over Jacob’s descendants forever; his kingdom will never end.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “How will this be,” Mary asked the angel, “since I am a virgin?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel answered, “The Holy Spirit will come on you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.
speaker: Jesus

text: Even Elizabeth your relative is going to have a child in her old age, and she who was said to be unable to conceive is in her sixth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: For no word from God will ever fail.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the Lord’s servant,” Mary answered. “May your word to me be fulfilled.” Then the angel left her.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Mary got ready and hurried to a town in the hill country of Judea,
speaker: Narrator

text: where she entered Zechariah’s home and greeted Elizabeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elizabeth heard Mary’s greeting, the baby leaped in her womb, and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text: In a loud voice she exclaimed: “Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the child you will bear!
speaker: Narrator

text: But why am I so favored, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the sound of your greeting reached my ears, the baby in my womb leaped for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is she who has believed that the Lord would fulfill his promises to her!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Mary said:
“My soul glorifies the Lord
speaker: Narrator

text: and my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for he has been mindful
    of the humble state of his servant.
From now on all generations will call me blessed,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the Mighty One has done great things for me—
    holy is his name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His mercy extends to those who fear him,
    from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has performed mighty deeds with his arm;
    he has scattered those who are proud in their inmost thoughts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has brought down rulers from their thrones
    but has lifted up the humble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has filled the hungry with good things
    but has sent the rich away empty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has helped his servant Israel,
    remembering to be merciful
speaker: Narrator

text:
to Abraham and his descendants forever,
    just as he promised our ancestors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Mary stayed with Elizabeth for about three months and then returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was time for Elizabeth to have her baby, she gave birth to a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown her great mercy, and they shared her joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day they came to circumcise the child, and they were going to name him after his father Zechariah,
speaker: Narrator

text: but his mother spoke up and said, “No! He is to be called John.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to her, “There is no one among your relatives who has that name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they made signs to his father, to find out what he would like to name the child.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked for a writing tablet, and to everyone’s astonishment he wrote, “His name is John.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue set free, and he began to speak, praising God.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the neighbors were filled with awe, and throughout the hill country of Judea people were talking about all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who heard this wondered about it, asking, “What then is this child going to be?” For the Lord’s hand was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Praise be to the Lord, the God of Israel,
    because he has come to his people and redeemed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has raised up a horn of salvation for us
    in the house of his servant David
speaker: Narrator

text: (as he said through his holy prophets of long ago),
speaker: Narrator

text:
salvation from our enemies
    and from the hand of all who hate us—
speaker: Narrator

text:
to show mercy to our ancestors
    and to remember his holy covenant,
speaker: Narrator

text: the oath he swore to our father Abraham:
speaker: Narrator

text:
to rescue us from the hand of our enemies,
    and to enable us to serve him without fear
speaker: Narrator

text: in holiness and righteousness before him all our days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you, my child, will be called a prophet of the Most High;
    for you will go on before the Lord to prepare the way for him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to give his people the knowledge of salvation
    through the forgiveness of their sins,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because of the tender mercy of our God,
    by which the rising sun will come to us from heaven
speaker: Narrator

text:
to shine on those living in darkness
    and in the shadow of death,
to guide our feet into the path of peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the child grew and became strong in spirit; and he lived in the wilderness until he appeared publicly to Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world.
speaker: Narrator

text: (This was the first census that took place while Quirinius was governor of Syria.)
speaker: Narrator

text: And everyone went to their own town to register.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born,
speaker: Narrator

text: and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Glory to God in the highest heaven,
    and on earth peace to those on whom his favor rests.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day, when it was time to circumcise the child, he was named Jesus, the name the angel had given him before he was conceived.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came for the purification rites required by the Law of Moses, Joseph and Mary took him to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord
speaker: Narrator

text: (as it is written in the Law of the Lord, “Every firstborn male is to be consecrated to the Lord”),
speaker: Narrator

text: and to offer a sacrifice in keeping with what is said in the Law of the Lord: “a pair of doves or two young pigeons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a man in Jerusalem called Simeon, who was righteous and devout. He was waiting for the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not die before he had seen the Lord’s Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moved by the Spirit, he went into the temple courts. When the parents brought in the child Jesus to do for him what the custom of the Law required,
speaker: Narrator

text: Simeon took him in his arms and praised God, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sovereign Lord, as you have promised,
    you may now dismiss your servant in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my eyes have seen your salvation,
speaker: Narrator

text: which you have prepared in the sight of all nations:
speaker: Narrator

text:
a light for revelation to the Gentiles,
    and the glory of your people Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The child’s father and mother marveled at what was said about him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Simeon blessed them and said to Mary, his mother: “This child is destined to cause the falling and rising of many in Israel, and to be a sign that will be spoken against,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the thoughts of many hearts will be revealed. And a sword will pierce your own soul too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: There was also a prophet, Anna, the daughter of Penuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was very old; she had lived with her husband seven years after her marriage,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then was a widow until she was eighty-four. She never left the temple but worshiped night and day, fasting and praying.
speaker: Narrator

text: Coming up to them at that very moment, she gave thanks to God and spoke about the child to all who were looking forward to the redemption of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph and Mary had done everything required by the Law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee to their own town of Nazareth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the child grew and became strong; he was filled with wisdom, and the grace of God was on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every year Jesus’ parents went to Jerusalem for the Festival of the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was twelve years old, they went up to the festival, according to the custom.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the festival was over, while his parents were returning home, the boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem, but they were unaware of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thinking he was in their company, they traveled on for a day. Then they began looking for him among their relatives and friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they did not find him, they went back to Jerusalem to look for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After three days they found him in the temple courts, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who heard him was amazed at his understanding and his answers.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his parents saw him, they were astonished. His mother said to him, “Son, why have you treated us like this? Your father and I have been anxiously searching for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why were you searching for me?” he asked. “Didn’t you know I had to be in my Father’s house?”
speaker: Jesus

text: But they did not understand what he was saying to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went down to Nazareth with them and was obedient to them. But his mother treasured all these things in her heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jesus grew in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and man.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar—when Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, Herod tetrarch of Galilee, his brother Philip tetrarch of Iturea and Traconitis, and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene—
speaker: Narrator

text: during the high-priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came to John son of Zechariah in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went into all the country around the Jordan, preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet:
“A voice of one calling in the wilderness,
‘Prepare the way for the Lord,
    make straight paths for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every valley shall be filled in,
    every mountain and hill made low.
The crooked roads shall become straight,
    the rough ways smooth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all people will see God’s salvation.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: John said to the crowds coming out to be baptized by him, “You brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the coming wrath?
speaker: Narrator

text: Produce fruit in keeping with repentance. And do not begin to say to yourselves, ‘We have Abraham as our father.’ For I tell you that out of these stones God can raise up children for Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ax is already at the root of the trees, and every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What should we do then?” the crowd asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: John answered, “Anyone who has two shirts should share with the one who has none, and anyone who has food should do the same.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Even tax collectors came to be baptized. “Teacher,” they asked, “what should we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t collect any more than you are required to,” he told them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then some soldiers asked him, “And what should we do?”
He replied, “Don’t extort money and don’t accuse people falsely—be content with your pay.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people were waiting expectantly and were all wondering in their hearts if John might possibly be the Messiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: John answered them all, “I baptize you with water. But one who is more powerful than I will come, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: His winnowing fork is in his hand to clear his threshing floor and to gather the wheat into his barn, but he will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And with many other words John exhorted the people and proclaimed the good news to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when John rebuked Herod the tetrarch because of his marriage to Herodias, his brother’s wife, and all the other evil things he had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: Herod added this to them all: He locked John up in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people were being baptized, Jesus was baptized too. And as he was praying, heaven was opened
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Holy Spirit descended on him in bodily form like a dove. And a voice came from heaven: “You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now Jesus himself was about thirty years old when he began his ministry. He was the son, so it was thought, of Joseph,
the son of Heli,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Matthat,
the son of Levi, the son of Melki,
the son of Jannai, the son of Joseph,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Mattathias, the son of Amos,
the son of Nahum, the son of Esli,
the son of Naggai,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Maath,
the son of Mattathias, the son of Semein,
the son of Josek, the son of Joda,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Joanan, the son of Rhesa,
the son of Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel,
the son of Neri,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Melki,
the son of Addi, the son of Cosam,
the son of Elmadam, the son of Er,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Joshua, the son of Eliezer,
the son of Jorim, the son of Matthat,
the son of Levi,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Simeon,
the son of Judah, the son of Joseph,
the son of Jonam, the son of Eliakim,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Melea, the son of Menna,
the son of Mattatha, the son of Nathan,
the son of David,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Jesse,
the son of Obed, the son of Boaz,
the son of Salmon, the son of Nahshon,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Amminadab, the son of Ram,
the son of Hezron, the son of Perez,
the son of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Jacob,
the son of Isaac, the son of Abraham,
the son of Terah, the son of Nahor,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Serug, the son of Reu,
the son of Peleg, the son of Eber,
the son of Shelah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Cainan,
the son of Arphaxad, the son of Shem,
the son of Noah, the son of Lamech,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Methuselah, the son of Enoch,
the son of Jared, the son of Mahalalel,
the son of Kenan,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the son of Enosh,
the son of Seth, the son of Adam,
the son of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, left the Jordan and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text: where for forty days he was tempted by the devil. He ate nothing during those days, and at the end of them he was hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: The devil said to him, “If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, “It is written: ‘Man shall not live on bread alone.’”
speaker: Jesus

text: The devil led him up to a high place and showed him in an instant all the kingdoms of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to him, “I will give you all their authority and splendor; it has been given to me, and I can give it to anyone I want to.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you worship me, it will all be yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, “It is written: ‘Worship the Lord your God and serve him only.’”
speaker: Jesus

text: The devil led him to Jerusalem and had him stand on the highest point of the temple. “If you are the Son of God,” he said, “throw yourself down from here.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
they will lift you up in their hands,
    so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, “It is said: ‘Do not put the Lord your God to the test.’”
speaker: Jesus

text: When the devil had finished all this tempting, he left him until an opportune time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit, and news about him spread through the whole countryside.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was teaching in their synagogues, and everyone praised him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to Nazareth, where he had been brought up, and on the Sabbath day he went into the synagogue, as was his custom. He stood up to read,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the scroll of the prophet Isaiah was handed to him. Unrolling it, he found the place where it is written:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Spirit of the Lord is on me,
    because he has anointed me
    to proclaim good news to the poor.
He has sent me to proclaim freedom for the prisoners
    and recovery of sight for the blind,
to set the oppressed free,
speaker: Jesus

text: to proclaim the year of the Lord’s favor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he rolled up the scroll, gave it back to the attendant and sat down. The eyes of everyone in the synagogue were fastened on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He began by saying to them, “Today this scripture is fulfilled in your hearing.”
speaker: Jesus

text: All spoke well of him and were amazed at the gracious words that came from his lips. “Isn’t this Joseph’s son?” they asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, “Surely you will quote this proverb to me: ‘Physician, heal yourself!’ And you will tell me, ‘Do here in your hometown what we have heard that you did in Capernaum.’”
speaker: Jesus

text: “Truly I tell you,” he continued, “no prophet is accepted in his hometown.
speaker: Jesus

text: I assure you that there were many widows in Israel in Elijah’s time, when the sky was shut for three and a half years and there was a severe famine throughout the land.
speaker: Jesus

text: Yet Elijah was not sent to any of them, but to a widow in Zarephath in the region of Sidon.
speaker: Jesus

text: And there were many in Israel with leprosy in the time of Elisha the prophet, yet not one of them was cleansed—only Naaman the Syrian.”
speaker: Jesus

text: All the people in the synagogue were furious when they heard this.
speaker: Jesus

text: They got up, drove him out of the town, and took him to the brow of the hill on which the town was built, in order to throw him off the cliff.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he walked right through the crowd and went on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went down to Capernaum, a town in Galilee, and on the Sabbath he taught the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were amazed at his teaching, because his words had authority.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the synagogue there was a man possessed by a demon, an impure spirit. He cried out at the top of his voice,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go away! What do you want with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!”
speaker: Jesus

text: “Be quiet!” Jesus said sternly. “Come out of him!” Then the demon threw the man down before them all and came out without injuring him.
speaker: Jesus

text: All the people were amazed and said to each other, “What words these are! With authority and power he gives orders to impure spirits and they come out!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the news about him spread throughout the surrounding area.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus left the synagogue and went to the home of Simon. Now Simon’s mother-in-law was suffering from a high fever, and they asked Jesus to help her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he bent over her and rebuked the fever, and it left her. She got up at once and began to wait on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: At sunset, the people brought to Jesus all who had various kinds of sickness, and laying his hands on each one, he healed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, demons came out of many people, shouting, “You are the Son of God!” But he rebuked them and would not allow them to speak, because they knew he was the Messiah.
speaker: Jesus

text: At daybreak, Jesus went out to a solitary place. The people were looking for him and when they came to where he was, they tried to keep him from leaving them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “I must proclaim the good news of the kingdom of God to the other towns also, because that is why I was sent.”
speaker: Jesus

text: And he kept on preaching in the synagogues of Judea.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as Jesus was standing by the Lake of Gennesaret, the people were crowding around him and listening to the word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He saw at the water’s edge two boats, left there by the fishermen, who were washing their nets.
speaker: Narrator

text: He got into one of the boats, the one belonging to Simon, and asked him to put out a little from shore. Then he sat down and taught the people from the boat.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, “Put out into deep water, and let down the nets for a catch.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Simon answered, “Master, we’ve worked hard all night and haven’t caught anything. But because you say so, I will let down the nets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had done so, they caught such a large number of fish that their nets began to break.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they signaled their partners in the other boat to come and help them, and they came and filled both boats so full that they began to sink.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Simon Peter saw this, he fell at Jesus’ knees and said, “Go away from me, Lord; I am a sinful man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For he and all his companions were astonished at the catch of fish they had taken,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and so were James and John, the sons of Zebedee, Simon’s partners.
Then Jesus said to Simon, “Don’t be afraid; from now on you will fish for people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they pulled their boats up on shore, left everything and followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jesus was in one of the towns, a man came along who was covered with leprosy. When he saw Jesus, he fell with his face to the ground and begged him, “Lord, if you are willing, you can make me clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus reached out his hand and touched the man. “I am willing,” he said. “Be clean!” And immediately the leprosy left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus ordered him, “Don’t tell anyone, but go, show yourself to the priest and offer the sacrifices that Moses commanded for your cleansing, as a testimony to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the news about him spread all the more, so that crowds of people came to hear him and to be healed of their sicknesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus often withdrew to lonely places and prayed.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus was teaching, and Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting there. They had come from every village of Galilee and from Judea and Jerusalem. And the power of the Lord was with Jesus to heal the sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men came carrying a paralyzed man on a mat and tried to take him into the house to lay him before Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they could not find a way to do this because of the crowd, they went up on the roof and lowered him on his mat through the tiles into the middle of the crowd, right in front of Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus saw their faith, he said, “Friend, your sins are forgiven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisees and the teachers of the law began thinking to themselves, “Who is this fellow who speaks blasphemy? Who can forgive sins but God alone?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus knew what they were thinking and asked, “Why are you thinking these things in your hearts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Which is easier: to say, ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or to say, ‘Get up and walk’?
speaker: Narrator

text: But I want you to know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins.” So he said to the paralyzed man, “I tell you, get up, take your mat and go home.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately he stood up in front of them, took what he had been lying on and went home praising God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone was amazed and gave praise to God. They were filled with awe and said, “We have seen remarkable things today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Jesus went out and saw a tax collector by the name of Levi sitting at his tax booth. “Follow me,” Jesus said to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Levi got up, left everything and followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Levi held a great banquet for Jesus at his house, and a large crowd of tax collectors and others were eating with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law who belonged to their sect complained to his disciples, “Why do you eat and drink with tax collectors and sinners?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, “It is not the healthy who need a doctor, but the sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “John’s disciples often fast and pray, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees, but yours go on eating and drinking.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, “Can you make the friends of the bridegroom fast while he is with them?
speaker: Narrator

text: But the time will come when the bridegroom will be taken from them; in those days they will fast.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them this parable: “No one tears a piece out of a new garment to patch an old one. Otherwise, they will have torn the new garment, and the patch from the new will not match the old.
speaker: Narrator

text: And no one pours new wine into old wineskins. Otherwise, the new wine will burst the skins; the wine will run out and the wineskins will be ruined.
speaker: Narrator

text: No, new wine must be poured into new wineskins.
speaker: Narrator

text: And no one after drinking old wine wants the new, for they say, ‘The old is better.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: One Sabbath Jesus was going through the grainfields, and his disciples began to pick some heads of grain, rub them in their hands and eat the kernels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Pharisees asked, “Why are you doing what is unlawful on the Sabbath?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered them, “Have you never read what David did when he and his companions were hungry?
speaker: Narrator

text: He entered the house of God, and taking the consecrated bread, he ate what is lawful only for priests to eat. And he also gave some to his companions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to them, “The Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On another Sabbath he went into the synagogue and was teaching, and a man was there whose right hand was shriveled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisees and the teachers of the law were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus, so they watched him closely to see if he would heal on the Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus knew what they were thinking and said to the man with the shriveled hand, “Get up and stand in front of everyone.” So he got up and stood there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to them, “I ask you, which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to destroy it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked around at them all, and then said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He did so, and his hand was completely restored.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law were furious and began to discuss with one another what they might do to Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of those days Jesus went out to a mountainside to pray, and spent the night praying to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning came, he called his disciples to him and chose twelve of them, whom he also designated apostles:
speaker: Narrator

text: Simon (whom he named Peter), his brother Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
speaker: Narrator

text: Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Simon who was called the Zealot,
speaker: Narrator

text: Judas son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went down with them and stood on a level place. A large crowd of his disciples was there and a great number of people from all over Judea, from Jerusalem, and from the coastal region around Tyre and Sidon,
speaker: Narrator

text: who had come to hear him and to be healed of their diseases. Those troubled by impure spirits were cured,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the people all tried to touch him, because power was coming from him and healing them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Looking at his disciples, he said:
“Blessed are you who are poor,
    for yours is the kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed are you who hunger now,
    for you will be satisfied.
Blessed are you who weep now,
    for you will laugh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed are you when people hate you,
    when they exclude you and insult you
    and reject your name as evil,
        because of the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Rejoice in that day and leap for joy, because great is your reward in heaven. For that is how their ancestors treated the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But woe to you who are rich,
    for you have already received your comfort.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to you who are well fed now,
    for you will go hungry.
Woe to you who laugh now,
    for you will mourn and weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to you when everyone speaks well of you,
    for that is how their ancestors treated the false prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But to you who are listening I say: Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you,
speaker: Narrator

text: bless those who curse you, pray for those who mistreat you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone slaps you on one cheek, turn to them the other also. If someone takes your coat, do not withhold your shirt from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give to everyone who asks you, and if anyone takes what belongs to you, do not demand it back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do to others as you would have them do to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you love those who love you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners love those who love them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you do good to those who are good to you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners do that.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you lend to those from whom you expect repayment, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners, expecting to be repaid in full.
speaker: Narrator

text: But love your enemies, do good to them, and lend to them without expecting to get anything back. Then your reward will be great, and you will be children of the Most High, because he is kind to the ungrateful and wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be merciful, just as your Father is merciful.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not judge, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn, and you will not be condemned. Forgive, and you will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give, and it will be given to you. A good measure, pressed down, shaken together and running over, will be poured into your lap. For with the measure you use, it will be measured to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also told them this parable: “Can the blind lead the blind? Will they not both fall into a pit?
speaker: Narrator

text: The student is not above the teacher, but everyone who is fully trained will be like their teacher.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why do you look at the speck of sawdust in your brother’s eye and pay no attention to the plank in your own eye?
speaker: Narrator

text: How can you say to your brother, ‘Brother, let me take the speck out of your eye,’ when you yourself fail to see the plank in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the plank out of your eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck from your brother’s eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No good tree bears bad fruit, nor does a bad tree bear good fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each tree is recognized by its own fruit. People do not pick figs from thornbushes, or grapes from briers.
speaker: Narrator

text: A good man brings good things out of the good stored up in his heart, and an evil man brings evil things out of the evil stored up in his heart. For the mouth speaks what the heart is full of.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why do you call me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ and do not do what I say?
speaker: Narrator

text: As for everyone who comes to me and hears my words and puts them into practice, I will show you what they are like.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are like a man building a house, who dug down deep and laid the foundation on rock. When a flood came, the torrent struck that house but could not shake it, because it was well built.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one who hears my words and does not put them into practice is like a man who built a house on the ground without a foundation. The moment the torrent struck that house, it collapsed and its destruction was complete.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had finished saying all this to the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum.
speaker: Narrator

text: There a centurion’s servant, whom his master valued highly, was sick and about to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The centurion heard of Jesus and sent some elders of the Jews to him, asking him to come and heal his servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to Jesus, they pleaded earnestly with him, “This man deserves to have you do this,
speaker: Narrator

text: because he loves our nation and has built our synagogue.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Jesus went with them.
He was not far from the house when the centurion sent friends to say to him: “Lord, don’t trouble yourself, for I do not deserve to have you come under my roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I did not even consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant will be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus heard this, he was amazed at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, “I tell you, I have not found such great faith even in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men who had been sent returned to the house and found the servant well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon afterward, Jesus went to a town called Nain, and his disciples and a large crowd went along with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he approached the town gate, a dead person was being carried out—the only son of his mother, and she was a widow. And a large crowd from the town was with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw her, his heart went out to her and he said, “Don’t cry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went up and touched the bier they were carrying him on, and the bearers stood still. He said, “Young man, I say to you, get up!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus gave him back to his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were all filled with awe and praised God. “A great prophet has appeared among us,” they said. “God has come to help his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This news about Jesus spread throughout Judea and the surrounding country.
speaker: Narrator

text: John’s disciples told him about all these things. Calling two of them,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent them to the Lord to ask, “Are you the one who is to come, or should we expect someone else?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men came to Jesus, they said, “John the Baptist sent us to you to ask, ‘Are you the one who is to come, or should we expect someone else?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that very time Jesus cured many who had diseases, sicknesses and evil spirits, and gave sight to many who were blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he replied to the messengers, “Go back and report to John what you have seen and heard: The blind receive sight, the lame walk, those who have leprosy are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, and the good news is proclaimed to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed is anyone who does not stumble on account of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After John’s messengers left, Jesus began to speak to the crowd about John: “What did you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed swayed by the wind?
speaker: Narrator

text: If not, what did you go out to see? A man dressed in fine clothes? No, those who wear expensive clothes and indulge in luxury are in palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text: But what did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and more than a prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the one about whom it is written:
“‘I will send my messenger ahead of you,
    who will prepare your way before you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, among those born of women there is no one greater than John; yet the one who is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (All the people, even the tax collectors, when they heard Jesus’ words, acknowledged that God’s way was right, because they had been baptized by John.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisees and the experts in the law rejected God’s purpose for themselves, because they had not been baptized by John.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus went on to say, “To what, then, can I compare the people of this generation? What are they like?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are like children sitting in the marketplace and calling out to each other:
“‘We played the pipe for you,
    and you did not dance;
we sang a dirge,
    and you did not cry.’
speaker: Narrator

text: For John the Baptist came neither eating bread nor drinking wine, and you say, ‘He has a demon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and you say, ‘Here is a glutton and a drunkard, a friend of tax collectors and sinners.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But wisdom is proved right by all her children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of the Pharisees invited Jesus to have dinner with him, he went to the Pharisee’s house and reclined at the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: A woman in that town who lived a sinful life learned that Jesus was eating at the Pharisee’s house, so she came there with an alabaster jar of perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text: As she stood behind him at his feet weeping, she began to wet his feet with her tears. Then she wiped them with her hair, kissed them and poured perfume on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, “If this man were a prophet, he would know who is touching him and what kind of woman she is—that she is a sinner.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus answered him, “Simon, I have something to tell you.”
“Tell me, teacher,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Two people owed money to a certain moneylender. One owed him five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither of them had the money to pay him back, so he forgave the debts of both. Now which of them will love him more?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Simon replied, “I suppose the one who had the bigger debt forgiven.”
“You have judged correctly,” Jesus said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned toward the woman and said to Simon, “Do you see this woman? I came into your house. You did not give me any water for my feet, but she wet my feet with her tears and wiped them with her hair.
speaker: Narrator

text: You did not give me a kiss, but this woman, from the time I entered, has not stopped kissing my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: You did not put oil on my head, but she has poured perfume on my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, I tell you, her many sins have been forgiven—as her great love has shown. But whoever has been forgiven little loves little.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to her, “Your sins are forgiven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The other guests began to say among themselves, “Who is this who even forgives sins?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you; go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Jesus traveled about from one town and village to another, proclaiming the good news of the kingdom of God. The Twelve were with him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and also some women who had been cured of evil spirits and diseases: Mary (called Magdalene) from whom seven demons had come out;
speaker: Narrator

text: Joanna the wife of Chuza, the manager of Herod’s household; Susanna; and many others. These women were helping to support them out of their own means.
speaker: Narrator

text: While a large crowd was gathering and people were coming to Jesus from town after town, he told this parable:
speaker: Narrator

text: “A farmer went out to sow his seed. As he was scattering the seed, some fell along the path; it was trampled on, and the birds ate it up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some fell on rocky ground, and when it came up, the plants withered because they had no moisture.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other seed fell among thorns, which grew up with it and choked the plants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Still other seed fell on good soil. It came up and yielded a crop, a hundred times more than was sown.”
When he said this, he called out, “Whoever has ears to hear, let them hear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His disciples asked him what this parable meant.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: “This is the meaning of the parable: The seed is the word of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those along the path are the ones who hear, and then the devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts, so that they may not believe and be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those on the rocky ground are the ones who receive the word with joy when they hear it, but they have no root. They believe for a while, but in the time of testing they fall away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seed that fell among thorns stands for those who hear, but as they go on their way they are choked by life’s worries, riches and pleasures, and they do not mature.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the seed on good soil stands for those with a noble and good heart, who hear the word, retain it, and by persevering produce a crop.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No one lights a lamp and hides it in a clay jar or puts it under a bed. Instead, they put it on a stand, so that those who come in can see the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there is nothing hidden that will not be disclosed, and nothing concealed that will not be known or brought out into the open.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore consider carefully how you listen. Whoever has will be given more; whoever does not have, even what they think they have will be taken from them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jesus’ mother and brothers came to see him, but they were not able to get near him because of the crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone told him, “Your mother and brothers are standing outside, wanting to see you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “My mother and brothers are those who hear God’s word and put it into practice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus said to his disciples, “Let us go over to the other side of the lake.” So they got into a boat and set out.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they sailed, he fell asleep. A squall came down on the lake, so that the boat was being swamped, and they were in great danger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The disciples went and woke him, saying, “Master, Master, we’re going to drown!”
He got up and rebuked the wind and the raging waters; the storm subsided, and all was calm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where is your faith?” he asked his disciples.
In fear and amazement they asked one another, “Who is this? He commands even the winds and the water, and they obey him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They sailed to the region of the Gerasenes, which is across the lake from Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus stepped ashore, he was met by a demon-possessed man from the town. For a long time this man had not worn clothes or lived in a house, but had lived in the tombs.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw Jesus, he cried out and fell at his feet, shouting at the top of his voice, “What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you, don’t torture me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For Jesus had commanded the impure spirit to come out of the man. Many times it had seized him, and though he was chained hand and foot and kept under guard, he had broken his chains and had been driven by the demon into solitary places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus asked him, “What is your name?”
“Legion,” he replied, because many demons had gone into him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they begged Jesus repeatedly not to order them to go into the Abyss.
speaker: Narrator

text: A large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside. The demons begged Jesus to let them go into the pigs, and he gave them permission.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the demons came out of the man, they went into the pigs, and the herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and was drowned.
speaker: Narrator

text: When those tending the pigs saw what had happened, they ran off and reported this in the town and countryside,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the people went out to see what had happened. When they came to Jesus, they found the man from whom the demons had gone out, sitting at Jesus’ feet, dressed and in his right mind; and they were afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who had seen it told the people how the demon-possessed man had been cured.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people of the region of the Gerasenes asked Jesus to leave them, because they were overcome with fear. So he got into the boat and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man from whom the demons had gone out begged to go with him, but Jesus sent him away, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Return home and tell how much God has done for you.” So the man went away and told all over town how much Jesus had done for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Jesus returned, a crowd welcomed him, for they were all expecting him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a man named Jairus, a synagogue leader, came and fell at Jesus’ feet, pleading with him to come to his house
speaker: Narrator

text:
because his only daughter, a girl of about twelve, was dying.
As Jesus was on his way, the crowds almost crushed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a woman was there who had been subject to bleeding for twelve years, but no one could heal her.
speaker: Narrator

text: She came up behind him and touched the edge of his cloak, and immediately her bleeding stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who touched me?” Jesus asked.
When they all denied it, Peter said, “Master, the people are crowding and pressing against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus said, “Someone touched me; I know that power has gone out from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman, seeing that she could not go unnoticed, came trembling and fell at his feet. In the presence of all the people, she told why she had touched him and how she had been instantly healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to her, “Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Jesus was still speaking, someone came from the house of Jairus, the synagogue leader. “Your daughter is dead,” he said. “Don’t bother the teacher anymore.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hearing this, Jesus said to Jairus, “Don’t be afraid; just believe, and she will be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived at the house of Jairus, he did not let anyone go in with him except Peter, John and James, and the child’s father and mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, all the people were wailing and mourning for her. “Stop wailing,” Jesus said. “She is not dead but asleep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They laughed at him, knowing that she was dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he took her by the hand and said, “My child, get up!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Her spirit returned, and at once she stood up. Then Jesus told them to give her something to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her parents were astonished, but he ordered them not to tell anyone what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had called the Twelve together, he gave them power and authority to drive out all demons and to cure diseases,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he sent them out to proclaim the kingdom of God and to heal the sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them: “Take nothing for the journey—no staff, no bag, no bread, no money, no extra shirt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever house you enter, stay there until you leave that town.
speaker: Narrator

text: If people do not welcome you, leave their town and shake the dust off your feet as a testimony against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they set out and went from village to village, proclaiming the good news and healing people everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Herod the tetrarch heard about all that was going on. And he was perplexed because some were saying that John had been raised from the dead,
speaker: Narrator

text: others that Elijah had appeared, and still others that one of the prophets of long ago had come back to life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Herod said, “I beheaded John. Who, then, is this I hear such things about?” And he tried to see him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the apostles returned, they reported to Jesus what they had done. Then he took them with him and they withdrew by themselves to a town called Bethsaida,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the crowds learned about it and followed him. He welcomed them and spoke to them about the kingdom of God, and healed those who needed healing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Late in the afternoon the Twelve came to him and said, “Send the crowd away so they can go to the surrounding villages and countryside and find food and lodging, because we are in a remote place here.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He replied, “You give them something to eat.”
They answered, “We have only five loaves of bread and two fish—unless we go and buy food for all this crowd.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
(About five thousand men were there.)
But he said to his disciples, “Have them sit down in groups of about fifty each.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The disciples did so, and everyone sat down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Taking the five loaves and the two fish and looking up to heaven, he gave thanks and broke them. Then he gave them to the disciples to distribute to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all ate and were satisfied, and the disciples picked up twelve basketfuls of broken pieces that were left over.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when Jesus was praying in private and his disciples were with him, he asked them, “Who do the crowds say I am?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “Some say John the Baptist; others say Elijah; and still others, that one of the prophets of long ago has come back to life.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But what about you?” he asked. “Who do you say I am?”
Peter answered, “God’s Messiah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus strictly warned them not to tell this to anyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “The Son of Man must suffer many things and be rejected by the elders, the chief priests and the teachers of the law, and he must be killed and on the third day be raised to life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to them all: “Whoever wants to be my disciple must deny themselves and take up their cross daily and follow me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For whoever wants to save their life will lose it, but whoever loses their life for me will save it.
speaker: Narrator

text: What good is it for someone to gain the whole world, and yet lose or forfeit their very self?
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever is ashamed of me and my words, the Son of Man will be ashamed of them when he comes in his glory and in the glory of the Father and of the holy angels.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Truly I tell you, some who are standing here will not taste death before they see the kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: About eight days after Jesus said this, he took Peter, John and James with him and went up onto a mountain to pray.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was praying, the appearance of his face changed, and his clothes became as bright as a flash of lightning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two men, Moses and Elijah, appeared in glorious splendor, talking with Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: They spoke about his departure, which he was about to bring to fulfillment at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter and his companions were very sleepy, but when they became fully awake, they saw his glory and the two men standing with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the men were leaving Jesus, Peter said to him, “Master, it is good for us to be here. Let us put up three shelters—one for you, one for Moses and one for Elijah.” (He did not know what he was saying.)
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was speaking, a cloud appeared and covered them, and they were afraid as they entered the cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: A voice came from the cloud, saying, “This is my Son, whom I have chosen; listen to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the voice had spoken, they found that Jesus was alone. The disciples kept this to themselves and did not tell anyone at that time what they had seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, when they came down from the mountain, a large crowd met him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man in the crowd called out, “Teacher, I beg you to look at my son, for he is my only child.
speaker: Narrator

text: A spirit seizes him and he suddenly screams; it throws him into convulsions so that he foams at the mouth. It scarcely ever leaves him and is destroying him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I begged your disciples to drive it out, but they could not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You unbelieving and perverse generation,” Jesus replied, “how long shall I stay with you and put up with you? Bring your son here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Even while the boy was coming, the demon threw him to the ground in a convulsion. But Jesus rebuked the impure spirit, healed the boy and gave him back to his father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they were all amazed at the greatness of God.
While everyone was marveling at all that Jesus did, he said to his disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen carefully to what I am about to tell you: The Son of Man is going to be delivered into the hands of men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not understand what this meant. It was hidden from them, so that they did not grasp it, and they were afraid to ask him about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: An argument started among the disciples as to which of them would be the greatest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus, knowing their thoughts, took a little child and had him stand beside him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to them, “Whoever welcomes this little child in my name welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me welcomes the one who sent me. For it is the one who is least among you all who is the greatest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Master,” said John, “we saw someone driving out demons in your name and we tried to stop him, because he is not one of us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not stop him,” Jesus said, “for whoever is not against you is for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the time approached for him to be taken up to heaven, Jesus resolutely set out for Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sent messengers on ahead, who went into a Samaritan village to get things ready for him;
speaker: Narrator

text: but the people there did not welcome him, because he was heading for Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the disciples James and John saw this, they asked, “Lord, do you want us to call fire down from heaven to destroy them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus turned and rebuked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he and his disciples went to another village.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were walking along the road, a man said to him, “I will follow you wherever you go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “Foxes have dens and birds have nests, but the Son of Man has no place to lay his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to another man, “Follow me.”
But he replied, “Lord, first let me go and bury my father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to him, “Let the dead bury their own dead, but you go and proclaim the kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Still another said, “I will follow you, Lord; but first let me go back and say goodbye to my family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “No one who puts a hand to the plow and looks back is fit for service in the kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them two by two ahead of him to every town and place where he was about to go.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not take a purse or bag or sandals; and do not greet anyone on the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter a house, first say, ‘Peace to this house.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone who promotes peace is there, your peace will rest on them; if not, it will return to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay there, eating and drinking whatever they give you, for the worker deserves his wages. Do not move around from house to house.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter a town and are welcomed, eat what is offered to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heal the sick who are there and tell them, ‘The kingdom of God has come near to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you enter a town and are not welcomed, go into its streets and say,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Even the dust of your town we wipe from our feet as a warning to you. Yet be sure of this: The kingdom of God has come near.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, it will be more bearable on that day for Sodom than for that town.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the miracles that were performed in you had been performed in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, Capernaum, will you be lifted to the heavens? No, you will go down to Hades.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever listens to you listens to me; whoever rejects you rejects me; but whoever rejects me rejects him who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Jesus, full of joy through the Holy Spirit, said, “I praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and learned, and revealed them to little children. Yes, Father, for this is what you were pleased to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All things have been committed to me by my Father. No one knows who the Son is except the Father, and no one knows who the Father is except the Son and those to whom the Son chooses to reveal him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he turned to his disciples and said privately, “Blessed are the eyes that see what you see.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I tell you that many prophets and kings wanted to see what you see but did not see it, and to hear what you hear but did not hear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On one occasion an expert in the law stood up to test Jesus. “Teacher,” he asked, “what must I do to inherit eternal life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What is written in the Law?” he replied. “How do you read it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength and with all your mind’; and, ‘Love your neighbor as yourself.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have answered correctly,” Jesus replied. “Do this and you will live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he wanted to justify himself, so he asked Jesus, “And who is my neighbor?”
speaker: Narrator

text: In reply Jesus said: “A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, when he was attacked by robbers. They stripped him of his clothes, beat him and went away, leaving him half dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: A priest happened to be going down the same road, and when he saw the man, he passed by on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text: So too, a Levite, when he came to the place and saw him, passed by on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a Samaritan, as he traveled, came where the man was; and when he saw him, he took pity on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to him and bandaged his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he put the man on his own donkey, brought him to an inn and took care of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day he took out two denarii and gave them to the innkeeper. ‘Look after him,’ he said, ‘and when I return, I will reimburse you for any extra expense you may have.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Which of these three do you think was a neighbor to the man who fell into the hands of robbers?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The expert in the law replied, “The one who had mercy on him.”
Jesus told him, “Go and do likewise.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus and his disciples were on their way, he came to a village where a woman named Martha opened her home to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: She had a sister called Mary, who sat at the Lord’s feet listening to what he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Martha was distracted by all the preparations that had to be made. She came to him and asked, “Lord, don’t you care that my sister has left me to do the work by myself? Tell her to help me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Martha, Martha,” the Lord answered, “you are worried and upset about many things,
speaker: Narrator

text: but few things are needed—or indeed only one. Mary has chosen what is better, and it will not be taken away from her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Jesus was praying in a certain place. When he finished, one of his disciples said to him, “Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his disciples.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to them, “When you pray, say:
“‘Father,
hallowed be your name,
your kingdom come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give us each day our daily bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Forgive us our sins,
    for we also forgive everyone who sins against us.
And lead us not into temptation.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to them, “Suppose you have a friend, and you go to him at midnight and say, ‘Friend, lend me three loaves of bread;
speaker: Narrator

text: a friend of mine on a journey has come to me, and I have no food to offer him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And suppose the one inside answers, ‘Don’t bother me. The door is already locked, and my children and I are in bed. I can’t get up and give you anything.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, even though he will not get up and give you the bread because of friendship, yet because of your shameless audacity he will surely get up and give you as much as you need.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I say to you: Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will find; knock and the door will be opened to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For everyone who asks receives; the one who seeks finds; and to the one who knocks, the door will be opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Which of you fathers, if your son asks for a fish, will give him a snake instead?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you then, though you are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father in heaven give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus was driving out a demon that was mute. When the demon left, the man who had been mute spoke, and the crowd was amazed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But some of them said, “By Beelzebul, the prince of demons, he is driving out demons.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Others tested him by asking for a sign from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus knew their thoughts and said to them: “Any kingdom divided against itself will be ruined, and a house divided against itself will fall.
speaker: Narrator

text: If Satan is divided against himself, how can his kingdom stand? I say this because you claim that I drive out demons by Beelzebul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if I drive out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your followers drive them out? So then, they will be your judges.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if I drive out demons by the finger of God, then the kingdom of God has come upon you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a strong man, fully armed, guards his own house, his possessions are safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when someone stronger attacks and overpowers him, he takes away the armor in which the man trusted and divides up his plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever is not with me is against me, and whoever does not gather with me scatters.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When an impure spirit comes out of a person, it goes through arid places seeking rest and does not find it. Then it says, ‘I will return to the house I left.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When it arrives, it finds the house swept clean and put in order.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it goes and takes seven other spirits more wicked than itself, and they go in and live there. And the final condition of that person is worse than the first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus was saying these things, a woman in the crowd called out, “Blessed is the mother who gave you birth and nursed you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Blessed rather are those who hear the word of God and obey it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As the crowds increased, Jesus said, “This is a wicked generation. It asks for a sign, but none will be given it except the sign of Jonah.
speaker: Narrator

text: For as Jonah was a sign to the Ninevites, so also will the Son of Man be to this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Queen of the South will rise at the judgment with the people of this generation and condemn them, for she came from the ends of the earth to listen to Solomon’s wisdom; and now something greater than Solomon is here.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Nineveh will stand up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, for they repented at the preaching of Jonah; and now something greater than Jonah is here.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No one lights a lamp and puts it in a place where it will be hidden, or under a bowl. Instead they put it on its stand, so that those who come in may see the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eye is the lamp of your body. When your eyes are healthy, your whole body also is full of light. But when they are unhealthy, your body also is full of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: See to it, then, that the light within you is not darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, if your whole body is full of light, and no part of it dark, it will be just as full of light as when a lamp shines its light on you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus had finished speaking, a Pharisee invited him to eat with him; so he went in and reclined at the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisee was surprised when he noticed that Jesus did not first wash before the meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to him, “Now then, you Pharisees clean the outside of the cup and dish, but inside you are full of greed and wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: You foolish people! Did not the one who made the outside make the inside also?
speaker: Narrator

text: But now as for what is inside you—be generous to the poor, and everything will be clean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to you Pharisees, because you give God a tenth of your mint, rue and all other kinds of garden herbs, but you neglect justice and the love of God. You should have practiced the latter without leaving the former undone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to you Pharisees, because you love the most important seats in the synagogues and respectful greetings in the marketplaces.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to you, because you are like unmarked graves, which people walk over without knowing it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the experts in the law answered him, “Teacher, when you say these things, you insult us also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “And you experts in the law, woe to you, because you load people down with burdens they can hardly carry, and you yourselves will not lift one finger to help them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to you, because you build tombs for the prophets, and it was your ancestors who killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you testify that you approve of what your ancestors did; they killed the prophets, and you build their tombs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this, God in his wisdom said, ‘I will send them prophets and apostles, some of whom they will kill and others they will persecute.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore this generation will be held responsible for the blood of all the prophets that has been shed since the beginning of the world,
speaker: Narrator

text: from the blood of Abel to the blood of Zechariah, who was killed between the altar and the sanctuary. Yes, I tell you, this generation will be held responsible for it all.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to you experts in the law, because you have taken away the key to knowledge. You yourselves have not entered, and you have hindered those who were entering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus went outside, the Pharisees and the teachers of the law began to oppose him fiercely and to besiege him with questions,
speaker: Narrator

text: waiting to catch him in something he might say.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, when a crowd of many thousands had gathered, so that they were trampling on one another, Jesus began to speak first to his disciples, saying: “Be on your guard against the yeast of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is nothing concealed that will not be disclosed, or hidden that will not be made known.
speaker: Narrator

text: What you have said in the dark will be heard in the daylight, and what you have whispered in the ear in the inner rooms will be proclaimed from the roofs.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell you, my friends, do not be afraid of those who kill the body and after that can do no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will show you whom you should fear: Fear him who, after your body has been killed, has authority to throw you into hell. Yes, I tell you, fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are not five sparrows sold for two pennies? Yet not one of them is forgotten by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the very hairs of your head are all numbered. Don’t be afraid; you are worth more than many sparrows.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell you, whoever publicly acknowledges me before others, the Son of Man will also acknowledge before the angels of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But whoever disowns me before others will be disowned before the angels of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And everyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but anyone who blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you are brought before synagogues, rulers and authorities, do not worry about how you will defend yourselves or what you will say,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Holy Spirit will teach you at that time what you should say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Someone in the crowd said to him, “Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “Man, who appointed me a judge or an arbiter between you?”
speaker: Narrator
