text: Then he said to them, “Watch out! Be on your guard against all kinds of greed; life does not consist in an abundance of possessions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he told them this parable: “The ground of a certain rich man yielded an abundant harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: He thought to himself, ‘What shall I do? I have no place to store my crops.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he said, ‘This is what I’ll do. I will tear down my barns and build bigger ones, and there I will store my surplus grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I’ll say to myself, “You have plenty of grain laid up for many years. Take life easy; eat, drink and be merry.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But God said to him, ‘You fool! This very night your life will be demanded from you. Then who will get what you have prepared for yourself?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is how it will be with whoever stores up things for themselves but is not rich toward God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to his disciples: “Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat; or about your body, what you will wear.
speaker: Narrator

text: For life is more than food, and the body more than clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider the ravens: They do not sow or reap, they have no storeroom or barn; yet God feeds them. And how much more valuable you are than birds!
speaker: Narrator

text: Who of you by worrying can add a single hour to your life?
speaker: Narrator

text: Since you cannot do this very little thing, why do you worry about the rest?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Consider how the wild flowers grow. They do not labor or spin. Yet I tell you, not even Solomon in all his splendor was dressed like one of these.
speaker: Narrator

text: If that is how God clothes the grass of the field, which is here today, and tomorrow is thrown into the fire, how much more will he clothe you—you of little faith!
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not set your heart on what you will eat or drink; do not worry about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the pagan world runs after all such things, and your Father knows that you need them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But seek his kingdom, and these things will be given to you as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not be afraid, little flock, for your Father has been pleased to give you the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sell your possessions and give to the poor. Provide purses for yourselves that will not wear out, a treasure in heaven that will never fail, where no thief comes near and no moth destroys.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be dressed ready for service and keep your lamps burning,
speaker: Narrator

text: like servants waiting for their master to return from a wedding banquet, so that when he comes and knocks they can immediately open the door for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be good for those servants whose master finds them watching when he comes. Truly I tell you, he will dress himself to serve, will have them recline at the table and will come and wait on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be good for those servants whose master finds them ready, even if he comes in the middle of the night or toward daybreak.
speaker: Narrator

text: But understand this: If the owner of the house had known at what hour the thief was coming, he would not have let his house be broken into.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also must be ready, because the Son of Man will come at an hour when you do not expect him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter asked, “Lord, are you telling this parable to us, or to everyone?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered, “Who then is the faithful and wise manager, whom the master puts in charge of his servants to give them their food allowance at the proper time?
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be good for that servant whom the master finds doing so when he returns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly I tell you, he will put him in charge of all his possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: But suppose the servant says to himself, ‘My master is taking a long time in coming,’ and he then begins to beat the other servants, both men and women, and to eat and drink and get drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: The master of that servant will come on a day when he does not expect him and at an hour he is not aware of. He will cut him to pieces and assign him a place with the unbelievers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The servant who knows the master’s will and does not get ready or does not do what the master wants will be beaten with many blows.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one who does not know and does things deserving punishment will be beaten with few blows. From everyone who has been given much, much will be demanded; and from the one who has been entrusted with much, much more will be asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have come to bring fire on the earth, and how I wish it were already kindled!
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have a baptism to undergo, and what constraint I am under until it is completed!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you think I came to bring peace on earth? No, I tell you, but division.
speaker: Narrator

text: From now on there will be five in one family divided against each other, three against two and two against three.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be divided, father against son and son against father, mother against daughter and daughter against mother, mother-in-law against daughter-in-law and daughter-in-law against mother-in-law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the crowd: “When you see a cloud rising in the west, immediately you say, ‘It’s going to rain,’ and it does.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the south wind blows, you say, ‘It’s going to be hot,’ and it is.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hypocrites! You know how to interpret the appearance of the earth and the sky. How is it that you don’t know how to interpret this present time?
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why don’t you judge for yourselves what is right?
speaker: Narrator

text: As you are going with your adversary to the magistrate, try hard to be reconciled on the way, or your adversary may drag you off to the judge, and the judge turn you over to the officer, and the officer throw you into prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, you will not get out until you have paid the last penny.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there were some present at that time who told Jesus about the Galileans whose blood Pilate had mixed with their sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, “Do you think that these Galileans were worse sinners than all the other Galileans because they suffered this way?
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, no! But unless you repent, you too will all perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or those eighteen who died when the tower in Siloam fell on them—do you think they were more guilty than all the others living in Jerusalem?
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, no! But unless you repent, you too will all perish.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told this parable: “A man had a fig tree growing in his vineyard, and he went to look for fruit on it but did not find any.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to the man who took care of the vineyard, ‘For three years now I’ve been coming to look for fruit on this fig tree and haven’t found any. Cut it down! Why should it use up the soil?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Sir,’ the man replied, ‘leave it alone for one more year, and I’ll dig around it and fertilize it.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it bears fruit next year, fine! If not, then cut it down.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: On a Sabbath Jesus was teaching in one of the synagogues,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a woman was there who had been crippled by a spirit for eighteen years. She was bent over and could not straighten up at all.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus saw her, he called her forward and said to her, “Woman, you are set free from your infirmity.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he put his hands on her, and immediately she straightened up and praised God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indignant because Jesus had healed on the Sabbath, the synagogue leader said to the people, “There are six days for work. So come and be healed on those days, not on the Sabbath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered him, “You hypocrites! Doesn’t each of you on the Sabbath untie your ox or donkey from the stall and lead it out to give it water?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then should not this woman, a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan has kept bound for eighteen long years, be set free on the Sabbath day from what bound her?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he said this, all his opponents were humiliated, but the people were delighted with all the wonderful things he was doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus asked, “What is the kingdom of God like? What shall I compare it to?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is like a mustard seed, which a man took and planted in his garden. It grew and became a tree, and the birds perched in its branches.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again he asked, “What shall I compare the kingdom of God to?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is like yeast that a woman took and mixed into about sixty pounds of flour until it worked all through the dough.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus went through the towns and villages, teaching as he made his way to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Someone asked him, “Lord, are only a few people going to be saved?”
He said to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Make every effort to enter through the narrow door, because many, I tell you, will try to enter and will not be able to.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once the owner of the house gets up and closes the door, you will stand outside knocking and pleading, ‘Sir, open the door for us.’
“But he will answer, ‘I don’t know you or where you come from.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then you will say, ‘We ate and drank with you, and you taught in our streets.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But he will reply, ‘I don’t know you or where you come from. Away from me, all you evildoers!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “There will be weeping there, and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham, Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, but you yourselves thrown out.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will come from east and west and north and south, and will take their places at the feast in the kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed there are those who are last who will be first, and first who will be last.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time some Pharisees came to Jesus and said to him, “Leave this place and go somewhere else. Herod wants to kill you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Go tell that fox, ‘I will keep on driving out demons and healing people today and tomorrow, and on the third day I will reach my goal.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In any case, I must press on today and tomorrow and the next day—for surely no prophet can die outside Jerusalem!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you who kill the prophets and stone those sent to you, how often I have longed to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and you were not willing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, your house is left to you desolate. I tell you, you will not see me again until you say, ‘Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: One Sabbath, when Jesus went to eat in the house of a prominent Pharisee, he was being carefully watched.
speaker: Narrator

text: There in front of him was a man suffering from abnormal swelling of his body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus asked the Pharisees and experts in the law, “Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they remained silent. So taking hold of the man, he healed him and sent him on his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he asked them, “If one of you has a child or an ox that falls into a well on the Sabbath day, will you not immediately pull it out?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they had nothing to say.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he noticed how the guests picked the places of honor at the table, he told them this parable:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When someone invites you to a wedding feast, do not take the place of honor, for a person more distinguished than you may have been invited.
speaker: Narrator

text: If so, the host who invited both of you will come and say to you, ‘Give this person your seat.’ Then, humiliated, you will have to take the least important place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you are invited, take the lowest place, so that when your host comes, he will say to you, ‘Friend, move up to a better place.’ Then you will be honored in the presence of all the other guests.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to his host, “When you give a luncheon or dinner, do not invite your friends, your brothers or sisters, your relatives, or your rich neighbors; if you do, they may invite you back and so you will be repaid.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you give a banquet, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you will be blessed. Although they cannot repay you, you will be repaid at the resurrection of the righteous.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of those at the table with him heard this, he said to Jesus, “Blessed is the one who will eat at the feast in the kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied: “A certain man was preparing a great banquet and invited many guests.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time of the banquet he sent his servant to tell those who had been invited, ‘Come, for everything is now ready.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But they all alike began to make excuses. The first said, ‘I have just bought a field, and I must go and see it. Please excuse me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Another said, ‘I have just bought five yoke of oxen, and I’m on my way to try them out. Please excuse me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Still another said, ‘I just got married, so I can’t come.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The servant came back and reported this to his master. Then the owner of the house became angry and ordered his servant, ‘Go out quickly into the streets and alleys of the town and bring in the poor, the crippled, the blind and the lame.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Sir,’ the servant said, ‘what you ordered has been done, but there is still room.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the master told his servant, ‘Go out to the roads and country lanes and compel them to come in, so that my house will be full.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, not one of those who were invited will get a taste of my banquet.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Large crowds were traveling with Jesus, and turning to them he said:
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone comes to me and does not hate father and mother, wife and children, brothers and sisters—yes, even their own life—such a person cannot be my disciple.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whoever does not carry their cross and follow me cannot be my disciple.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose one of you wants to build a tower. Won’t you first sit down and estimate the cost to see if you have enough money to complete it?
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you lay the foundation and are not able to finish it, everyone who sees it will ridicule you,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, ‘This person began to build and wasn’t able to finish.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Or suppose a king is about to go to war against another king. Won’t he first sit down and consider whether he is able with ten thousand men to oppose the one coming against him with twenty thousand?
speaker: Narrator

text: If he is not able, he will send a delegation while the other is still a long way off and will ask for terms of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, those of you who do not give up everything you have cannot be my disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Salt is good, but if it loses its saltiness, how can it be made salty again?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is fit neither for the soil nor for the manure pile; it is thrown out.
“Whoever has ears to hear, let them hear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the tax collectors and sinners were all gathering around to hear Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law muttered, “This man welcomes sinners and eats with them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told them this parable:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose one of you has a hundred sheep and loses one of them. Doesn’t he leave the ninety-nine in the open country and go after the lost sheep until he finds it?
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he finds it, he joyfully puts it on his shoulders
speaker: Narrator

text: and goes home. Then he calls his friends and neighbors together and says, ‘Rejoice with me; I have found my lost sheep.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you that in the same way there will be more rejoicing in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous persons who do not need to repent.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Or suppose a woman has ten silver coins and loses one. Doesn’t she light a lamp, sweep the house and search carefully until she finds it?
speaker: Narrator

text: And when she finds it, she calls her friends and neighbors together and says, ‘Rejoice with me; I have found my lost coin.’
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, I tell you, there is rejoicing in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner who repents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus continued: “There was a man who had two sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The younger one said to his father, ‘Father, give me my share of the estate.’ So he divided his property between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Not long after that, the younger son got together all he had, set off for a distant country and there squandered his wealth in wild living.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had spent everything, there was a severe famine in that whole country, and he began to be in need.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went and hired himself out to a citizen of that country, who sent him to his fields to feed pigs.
speaker: Narrator

text: He longed to fill his stomach with the pods that the pigs were eating, but no one gave him anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When he came to his senses, he said, ‘How many of my father’s hired servants have food to spare, and here I am starving to death!
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set out and go back to my father and say to him: Father, I have sinned against heaven and against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am no longer worthy to be called your son; make me like one of your hired servants.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he got up and went to his father.
“But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and was filled with compassion for him; he ran to his son, threw his arms around him and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The son said to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and against you. I am no longer worthy to be called your son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the father said to his servants, ‘Quick! Bring the best robe and put it on him. Put a ring on his finger and sandals on his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the fattened calf and kill it. Let’s have a feast and celebrate.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this son of mine was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.’ So they began to celebrate.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Meanwhile, the older son was in the field. When he came near the house, he heard music and dancing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he called one of the servants and asked him what was going on.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Your brother has come,’ he replied, ‘and your father has killed the fattened calf because he has him back safe and sound.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The older brother became angry and refused to go in. So his father went out and pleaded with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he answered his father, ‘Look! All these years I’ve been slaving for you and never disobeyed your orders. Yet you never gave me even a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when this son of yours who has squandered your property with prostitutes comes home, you kill the fattened calf for him!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘My son,’ the father said, ‘you are always with me, and everything I have is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we had to celebrate and be glad, because this brother of yours was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus told his disciples: “There was a rich man whose manager was accused of wasting his possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he called him in and asked him, ‘What is this I hear about you? Give an account of your management, because you cannot be manager any longer.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The manager said to himself, ‘What shall I do now? My master is taking away my job. I’m not strong enough to dig, and I’m ashamed to beg—
speaker: Narrator

text: I know what I’ll do so that, when I lose my job here, people will welcome me into their houses.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So he called in each one of his master’s debtors. He asked the first, ‘How much do you owe my master?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“‘Nine hundred gallons of olive oil,’ he replied.
“The manager told him, ‘Take your bill, sit down quickly, and make it four hundred and fifty.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then he asked the second, ‘And how much do you owe?’
“‘A thousand bushels of wheat,’ he replied.
“He told him, ‘Take your bill and make it eight hundred.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The master commended the dishonest manager because he had acted shrewdly. For the people of this world are more shrewd in dealing with their own kind than are the people of the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, use worldly wealth to gain friends for yourselves, so that when it is gone, you will be welcomed into eternal dwellings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever can be trusted with very little can also be trusted with much, and whoever is dishonest with very little will also be dishonest with much.
speaker: Narrator

text: So if you have not been trustworthy in handling worldly wealth, who will trust you with true riches?
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you have not been trustworthy with someone else’s property, who will give you property of your own?
speaker: Narrator

text: “No one can serve two masters. Either you will hate the one and love the other, or you will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisees, who loved money, heard all this and were sneering at Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “You are the ones who justify yourselves in the eyes of others, but God knows your hearts. What people value highly is detestable in God’s sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Law and the Prophets were proclaimed until John. Since that time, the good news of the kingdom of God is being preached, and everyone is forcing their way into it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is easier for heaven and earth to disappear than for the least stroke of a pen to drop out of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery, and the man who marries a divorced woman commits adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “There was a rich man who was dressed in purple and fine linen and lived in luxury every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: At his gate was laid a beggar named Lazarus, covered with sores
speaker: Narrator

text: and longing to eat what fell from the rich man’s table. Even the dogs came and licked his sores.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The time came when the beggar died and the angels carried him to Abraham’s side. The rich man also died and was buried.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Hades, where he was in torment, he looked up and saw Abraham far away, with Lazarus by his side.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he called to him, ‘Father Abraham, have pity on me and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, because I am in agony in this fire.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But Abraham replied, ‘Son, remember that in your lifetime you received your good things, while Lazarus received bad things, but now he is comforted here and you are in agony.
speaker: Narrator

text: And besides all this, between us and you a great chasm has been set in place, so that those who want to go from here to you cannot, nor can anyone cross over from there to us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “He answered, ‘Then I beg you, father, send Lazarus to my family,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I have five brothers. Let him warn them, so that they will not also come to this place of torment.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Abraham replied, ‘They have Moses and the Prophets; let them listen to them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘No, father Abraham,’ he said, ‘but if someone from the dead goes to them, they will repent.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “He said to him, ‘If they do not listen to Moses and the Prophets, they will not be convinced even if someone rises from the dead.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to his disciples: “Things that cause people to stumble are bound to come, but woe to anyone through whom they come.
speaker: Narrator

text: It would be better for them to be thrown into the sea with a millstone tied around their neck than to cause one of these little ones to stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So watch yourselves.
“If your brother or sister sins against you, rebuke them; and if they repent, forgive them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if they sin against you seven times in a day and seven times come back to you saying ‘I repent,’ you must forgive them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The apostles said to the Lord, “Increase our faith!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “If you have faith as small as a mustard seed, you can say to this mulberry tree, ‘Be uprooted and planted in the sea,’ and it will obey you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose one of you has a servant plowing or looking after the sheep. Will he say to the servant when he comes in from the field, ‘Come along now and sit down to eat’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Won’t he rather say, ‘Prepare my supper, get yourself ready and wait on me while I eat and drink; after that you may eat and drink’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will he thank the servant because he did what he was told to do?
speaker: Narrator

text: So you also, when you have done everything you were told to do, should say, ‘We are unworthy servants; we have only done our duty.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on his way to Jerusalem, Jesus traveled along the border between Samaria and Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was going into a village, ten men who had leprosy met him. They stood at a distance
speaker: Narrator

text: and called out in a loud voice, “Jesus, Master, have pity on us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw them, he said, “Go, show yourselves to the priests.” And as they went, they were cleansed.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them, when he saw he was healed, came back, praising God in a loud voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: He threw himself at Jesus’ feet and thanked him—and he was a Samaritan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus asked, “Were not all ten cleansed? Where are the other nine?
speaker: Narrator

text: Has no one returned to give praise to God except this foreigner?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “Rise and go; your faith has made you well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Once, on being asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, Jesus replied, “The coming of the kingdom of God is not something that can be observed,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor will people say, ‘Here it is,’ or ‘There it is,’ because the kingdom of God is in your midst.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to his disciples, “The time is coming when you will long to see one of the days of the Son of Man, but you will not see it.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will tell you, ‘There he is!’ or ‘Here he is!’ Do not go running off after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Son of Man in his day will be like the lightning, which flashes and lights up the sky from one end to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: But first he must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Just as it was in the days of Noah, so also will it be in the days of the Son of Man.
speaker: Narrator

text: People were eating, drinking, marrying and being given in marriage up to the day Noah entered the ark. Then the flood came and destroyed them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It was the same in the days of Lot. People were eating and drinking, buying and selling, planting and building.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the day Lot left Sodom, fire and sulfur rained down from heaven and destroyed them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It will be just like this on the day the Son of Man is revealed.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day no one who is on the housetop, with possessions inside, should go down to get them. Likewise, no one in the field should go back for anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember Lot’s wife!
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever tries to keep their life will lose it, and whoever loses their life will preserve it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, on that night two people will be in one bed; one will be taken and the other left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two women will be grinding grain together; one will be taken and the other left.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where, Lord?” they asked.
He replied, “Where there is a dead body, there the vultures will gather.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus told his disciples a parable to show them that they should always pray and not give up.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said: “In a certain town there was a judge who neither feared God nor cared what people thought.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was a widow in that town who kept coming to him with the plea, ‘Grant me justice against my adversary.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “For some time he refused. But finally he said to himself, ‘Even though I don’t fear God or care what people think,
speaker: Narrator

text: yet because this widow keeps bothering me, I will see that she gets justice, so that she won’t eventually come and attack me!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “Listen to what the unjust judge says.
speaker: Narrator

text: And will not God bring about justice for his chosen ones, who cry out to him day and night? Will he keep putting them off?
speaker: Narrator

text: I tell you, he will see that they get justice, and quickly. However, when the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on the earth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: To some who were confident of their own righteousness and looked down on everyone else, Jesus told this parable:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed: ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other people—robbers, evildoers, adulterers—or even like this tax collector.
speaker: Narrator

text: I fast twice a week and give a tenth of all I get.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the tax collector stood at a distance. He would not even look up to heaven, but beat his breast and said, ‘God, have mercy on me, a sinner.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell you that this man, rather than the other, went home justified before God. For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: People were also bringing babies to Jesus for him to place his hands on them. When the disciples saw this, they rebuked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus called the children to him and said, “Let the little children come to me, and do not hinder them, for the kingdom of God belongs to such as these.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly I tell you, anyone who will not receive the kingdom of God like a little child will never enter it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A certain ruler asked him, “Good teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why do you call me good?” Jesus answered. “No one is good—except God alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know the commandments: ‘You shall not commit adultery, you shall not murder, you shall not steal, you shall not give false testimony, honor your father and mother.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “All these I have kept since I was a boy,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus heard this, he said to him, “You still lack one thing. Sell everything you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard this, he became very sad, because he was very wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus looked at him and said, “How hard it is for the rich to enter the kingdom of God!
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for someone who is rich to enter the kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who heard this asked, “Who then can be saved?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “What is impossible with man is possible with God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter said to him, “We have left all we had to follow you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Truly I tell you,” Jesus said to them, “no one who has left home or wife or brothers or sisters or parents or children for the sake of the kingdom of God
speaker: Narrator

text: will fail to receive many times as much in this age, and in the age to come eternal life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus took the Twelve aside and told them, “We are going up to Jerusalem, and everything that is written by the prophets about the Son of Man will be fulfilled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be delivered over to the Gentiles. They will mock him, insult him and spit on him;
speaker: Narrator

text: they will flog him and kill him. On the third day he will rise again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The disciples did not understand any of this. Its meaning was hidden from them, and they did not know what he was talking about.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus approached Jericho, a blind man was sitting by the roadside begging.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard the crowd going by, he asked what was happening.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “Jesus of Nazareth is passing by.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He called out, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who led the way rebuked him and told him to be quiet, but he shouted all the more, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus stopped and ordered the man to be brought to him. When he came near, Jesus asked him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What do you want me to do for you?”
“Lord, I want to see,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to him, “Receive your sight; your faith has healed you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus, praising God. When all the people saw it, they also praised God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus entered Jericho and was passing through.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man was there by the name of Zacchaeus; he was a chief tax collector and was wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He wanted to see who Jesus was, but because he was short he could not see over the crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he ran ahead and climbed a sycamore-fig tree to see him, since Jesus was coming that way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus reached the spot, he looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus, come down immediately. I must stay at your house today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he came down at once and welcomed him gladly.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people saw this and began to mutter, “He has gone to be the guest of a sinner.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zacchaeus stood up and said to the Lord, “Look, Lord! Here and now I give half of my possessions to the poor, and if I have cheated anybody out of anything, I will pay back four times the amount.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come to this house, because this man, too, is a son of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were listening to this, he went on to tell them a parable, because he was near Jerusalem and the people thought that the kingdom of God was going to appear at once.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said: “A man of noble birth went to a distant country to have himself appointed king and then to return.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he called ten of his servants and gave them ten minas. ‘Put this money to work,’ he said, ‘until I come back.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But his subjects hated him and sent a delegation after him to say, ‘We don’t want this man to be our king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “He was made king, however, and returned home. Then he sent for the servants to whom he had given the money, in order to find out what they had gained with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The first one came and said, ‘Sir, your mina has earned ten more.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Well done, my good servant!’ his master replied. ‘Because you have been trustworthy in a very small matter, take charge of ten cities.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The second came and said, ‘Sir, your mina has earned five more.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “His master answered, ‘You take charge of five cities.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then another servant came and said, ‘Sir, here is your mina; I have kept it laid away in a piece of cloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was afraid of you, because you are a hard man. You take out what you did not put in and reap what you did not sow.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “His master replied, ‘I will judge you by your own words, you wicked servant! You knew, did you, that I am a hard man, taking out what I did not put in, and reaping what I did not sow?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why then didn’t you put my money on deposit, so that when I came back, I could have collected it with interest?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he said to those standing by, ‘Take his mina away from him and give it to the one who has ten minas.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Sir,’ they said, ‘he already has ten!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “He replied, ‘I tell you that to everyone who has, more will be given, but as for the one who has nothing, even what they have will be taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those enemies of mine who did not want me to be king over them—bring them here and kill them in front of me.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jesus had said this, he went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he approached Bethphage and Bethany at the hill called the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples, saying to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go to the village ahead of you, and as you enter it, you will find a colt tied there, which no one has ever ridden. Untie it and bring it here.
speaker: Narrator

text: If anyone asks you, ‘Why are you untying it?’ say, ‘The Lord needs it.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who were sent ahead went and found it just as he had told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were untying the colt, its owners asked them, “Why are you untying the colt?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “The Lord needs it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought it to Jesus, threw their cloaks on the colt and put Jesus on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he went along, people spread their cloaks on the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came near the place where the road goes down the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of disciples began joyfully to praise God in loud voices for all the miracles they had seen:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Blessed is the king who comes in the name of the Lord!”
“Peace in heaven and glory in the highest!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Pharisees in the crowd said to Jesus, “Teacher, rebuke your disciples!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I tell you,” he replied, “if they keep quiet, the stones will cry out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he approached Jerusalem and saw the city, he wept over it
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “If you, even you, had only known on this day what would bring you peace—but now it is hidden from your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The days will come upon you when your enemies will build an embankment against you and encircle you and hem you in on every side.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will dash you to the ground, you and the children within your walls. They will not leave one stone on another, because you did not recognize the time of God’s coming to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus entered the temple courts, he began to drive out those who were selling.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is written,” he said to them, “‘My house will be a house of prayer’; but you have made it ‘a den of robbers.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day he was teaching at the temple. But the chief priests, the teachers of the law and the leaders among the people were trying to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they could not find any way to do it, because all the people hung on his words.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as Jesus was teaching the people in the temple courts and proclaiming the good news, the chief priests and the teachers of the law, together with the elders, came up to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell us by what authority you are doing these things,” they said. “Who gave you this authority?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “I will also ask you a question. Tell me:
speaker: Narrator

text: John’s baptism—was it from heaven, or of human origin?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They discussed it among themselves and said, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will ask, ‘Why didn’t you believe him?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But if we say, ‘Of human origin,’ all the people will stone us, because they are persuaded that John was a prophet.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they answered, “We don’t know where it was from.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I am doing these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went on to tell the people this parable: “A man planted a vineyard, rented it to some farmers and went away for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: At harvest time he sent a servant to the tenants so they would give him some of the fruit of the vineyard. But the tenants beat him and sent him away empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent another servant, but that one also they beat and treated shamefully and sent away empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent still a third, and they wounded him and threw him out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the owner of the vineyard said, ‘What shall I do? I will send my son, whom I love; perhaps they will respect him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But when the tenants saw him, they talked the matter over. ‘This is the heir,’ they said. ‘Let’s kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him.
“What then will the owner of the vineyard do to them?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will come and kill those tenants and give the vineyard to others.”
When the people heard this, they said, “God forbid!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jesus looked directly at them and asked, “Then what is the meaning of that which is written:
“‘The stone the builders rejected
    has become the cornerstone’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who falls on that stone will be broken to pieces; anyone on whom it falls will be crushed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The teachers of the law and the chief priests looked for a way to arrest him immediately, because they knew he had spoken this parable against them. But they were afraid of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keeping a close watch on him, they sent spies, who pretended to be sincere. They hoped to catch Jesus in something he said, so that they might hand him over to the power and authority of the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the spies questioned him: “Teacher, we know that you speak and teach what is right, and that you do not show partiality but teach the way of God in accordance with the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it right for us to pay taxes to Caesar or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He saw through their duplicity and said to them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Show me a denarius. Whose image and inscription are on it?”
“Caesar’s,” they replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Then give back to Caesar what is Caesar’s, and to God what is God’s.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were unable to trap him in what he had said there in public. And astonished by his answer, they became silent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to Jesus with a question.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Teacher,” they said, “Moses wrote for us that if a man’s brother dies and leaves a wife but no children, the man must marry the widow and raise up offspring for his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there were seven brothers. The first one married a woman and died childless.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second
speaker: Narrator

text: and then the third married her, and in the same way the seven died, leaving no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, the woman died too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, at the resurrection whose wife will she be, since the seven were married to her?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus replied, “The people of this age marry and are given in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those who are considered worthy of taking part in the age to come and in the resurrection from the dead will neither marry nor be given in marriage,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they can no longer die; for they are like the angels. They are God’s children, since they are children of the resurrection.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the account of the burning bush, even Moses showed that the dead rise, for he calls the Lord ‘the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He is not the God of the dead, but of the living, for to him all are alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the teachers of the law responded, “Well said, teacher!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And no one dared to ask him any more questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to them, “Why is it said that the Messiah is the son of David?
speaker: Narrator

text:
David himself declares in the Book of Psalms:
“‘The Lord said to my Lord:
    “Sit at my right hand
speaker: Narrator

text:
until I make your enemies
    a footstool for your feet.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: David calls him ‘Lord.’ How then can he be his son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: While all the people were listening, Jesus said to his disciples,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Beware of the teachers of the law. They like to walk around in flowing robes and love to be greeted with respect in the marketplaces and have the most important seats in the synagogues and the places of honor at banquets.
speaker: Narrator

text: They devour widows’ houses and for a show make lengthy prayers. These men will be punished most severely.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jesus looked up, he saw the rich putting their gifts into the temple treasury.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also saw a poor widow put in two very small copper coins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Truly I tell you,” he said, “this poor widow has put in more than all the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these people gave their gifts out of their wealth; but she out of her poverty put in all she had to live on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of his disciples were remarking about how the temple was adorned with beautiful stones and with gifts dedicated to God. But Jesus said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for what you see here, the time will come when not one stone will be left on another; every one of them will be thrown down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Teacher,” they asked, “when will these things happen? And what will be the sign that they are about to take place?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied: “Watch out that you are not deceived. For many will come in my name, claiming, ‘I am he,’ and, ‘The time is near.’ Do not follow them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hear of wars and uprisings, do not be frightened. These things must happen first, but the end will not come right away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to them: “Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be great earthquakes, famines and pestilences in various places, and fearful events and great signs from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But before all this, they will seize you and persecute you. They will hand you over to synagogues and put you in prison, and you will be brought before kings and governors, and all on account of my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so you will bear testimony to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But make up your mind not to worry beforehand how you will defend yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will give you words and wisdom that none of your adversaries will be able to resist or contradict.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be betrayed even by parents, brothers and sisters, relatives and friends, and they will put some of you to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone will hate you because of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But not a hair of your head will perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stand firm, and you will win life.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you see Jerusalem being surrounded by armies, you will know that its desolation is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, let those in the city get out, and let those in the country not enter the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is the time of punishment in fulfillment of all that has been written.
speaker: Narrator

text: How dreadful it will be in those days for pregnant women and nursing mothers! There will be great distress in the land and wrath against this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will fall by the sword and will be taken as prisoners to all the nations. Jerusalem will be trampled on by the Gentiles until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.
speaker: Narrator

text: “There will be signs in the sun, moon and stars. On the earth, nations will be in anguish and perplexity at the roaring and tossing of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: People will faint from terror, apprehensive of what is coming on the world, for the heavenly bodies will be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time they will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: When these things begin to take place, stand up and lift up your heads, because your redemption is drawing near.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them this parable: “Look at the fig tree and all the trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they sprout leaves, you can see for yourselves and know that summer is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, when you see these things happening, you know that the kingdom of God is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Truly I tell you, this generation will certainly not pass away until all these things have happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be careful, or your hearts will be weighed down with carousing, drunkenness and the anxieties of life, and that day will close on you suddenly like a trap.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it will come on all those who live on the face of the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be always on the watch, and pray that you may be able to escape all that is about to happen, and that you may be able to stand before the Son of Man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Each day Jesus was teaching at the temple, and each evening he went out to spend the night on the hill called the Mount of Olives,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the people came early in the morning to hear him at the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Festival of Unleavened Bread, called the Passover, was approaching,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the chief priests and the teachers of the law were looking for some way to get rid of Jesus, for they were afraid of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Satan entered Judas, called Iscariot, one of the Twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Judas went to the chief priests and the officers of the temple guard and discussed with them how he might betray Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were delighted and agreed to give him money.
speaker: Narrator

text: He consented, and watched for an opportunity to hand Jesus over to them when no crowd was present.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then came the day of Unleavened Bread on which the Passover lamb had to be sacrificed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus sent Peter and John, saying, “Go and make preparations for us to eat the Passover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Where do you want us to prepare for it?” they asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “As you enter the city, a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him to the house that he enters,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say to the owner of the house, ‘The Teacher asks: Where is the guest room, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He will show you a large room upstairs, all furnished. Make preparations there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They left and found things just as Jesus had told them. So they prepared the Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the hour came, Jesus and his apostles reclined at the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to them, “I have eagerly desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I tell you, I will not eat it again until it finds fulfillment in the kingdom of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After taking the cup, he gave thanks and said, “Take this and divide it among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I tell you I will not drink again from the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he took bread, gave thanks and broke it, and gave it to them, saying, “This is my body given for you; do this in remembrance of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same way, after the supper he took the cup, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in my blood, which is poured out for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the hand of him who is going to betray me is with mine on the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Son of Man will go as it has been decreed. But woe to that man who betrays him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They began to question among themselves which of them it might be who would do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: A dispute also arose among them as to which of them was considered to be greatest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said to them, “The kings of the Gentiles lord it over them; and those who exercise authority over them call themselves Benefactors.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you are not to be like that. Instead, the greatest among you should be like the youngest, and the one who rules like the one who serves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who is greater, the one who is at the table or the one who serves? Is it not the one who is at the table? But I am among you as one who serves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are those who have stood by me in my trials.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I confer on you a kingdom, just as my Father conferred one on me,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom and sit on thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Simon, Simon, Satan has asked to sift all of you as wheat.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have prayed for you, Simon, that your faith may not fail. And when you have turned back, strengthen your brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he replied, “Lord, I am ready to go with you to prison and to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered, “I tell you, Peter, before the rooster crows today, you will deny three times that you know me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jesus asked them, “When I sent you without purse, bag or sandals, did you lack anything?”
“Nothing,” they answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “But now if you have a purse, take it, and also a bag; and if you don’t have a sword, sell your cloak and buy one.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is written: ‘And he was numbered with the transgressors’; and I tell you that this must be fulfilled in me. Yes, what is written about me is reaching its fulfillment.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The disciples said, “See, Lord, here are two swords.”
“That’s enough!” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus went out as usual to the Mount of Olives, and his disciples followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On reaching the place, he said to them, “Pray that you will not fall into temptation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He withdrew about a stone’s throw beyond them, knelt down and prayed,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Father, if you are willing, take this cup from me; yet not my will, but yours be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: An angel from heaven appeared to him and strengthened him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And being in anguish, he prayed more earnestly, and his sweat was like drops of blood falling to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he rose from prayer and went back to the disciples, he found them asleep, exhausted from sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Why are you sleeping?” he asked them. “Get up and pray so that you will not fall into temptation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking a crowd came up, and the man who was called Judas, one of the Twelve, was leading them. He approached Jesus to kiss him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Jesus asked him, “Judas, are you betraying the Son of Man with a kiss?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jesus’ followers saw what was going to happen, they said, “Lord, should we strike with our swords?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And one of them struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his right ear.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jesus answered, “No more of this!” And he touched the man’s ear and healed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jesus said to the chief priests, the officers of the temple guard, and the elders, who had come for him, “Am I leading a rebellion, that you have come with swords and clubs?
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day I was with you in the temple courts, and you did not lay a hand on me. But this is your hour—when darkness reigns.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then seizing him, they led him away and took him into the house of the high priest. Peter followed at a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when some there had kindled a fire in the middle of the courtyard and had sat down together, Peter sat down with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A servant girl saw him seated there in the firelight. She looked closely at him and said, “This man was with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he denied it. “Woman, I don’t know him,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A little later someone else saw him and said, “You also are one of them.”
“Man, I am not!” Peter replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: About an hour later another asserted, “Certainly this fellow was with him, for he is a Galilean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter replied, “Man, I don’t know what you’re talking about!” Just as he was speaking, the rooster crowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord turned and looked straight at Peter. Then Peter remembered the word the Lord had spoken to him: “Before the rooster crows today, you will disown me three times.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he went outside and wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men who were guarding Jesus began mocking and beating him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They blindfolded him and demanded, “Prophesy! Who hit you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said many other insulting things to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: At daybreak the council of the elders of the people, both the chief priests and the teachers of the law, met together, and Jesus was led before them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you are the Messiah,” they said, “tell us.”
Jesus answered, “If I tell you, you will not believe me,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if I asked you, you would not answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from now on, the Son of Man will be seated at the right hand of the mighty God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They all asked, “Are you then the Son of God?”
He replied, “You say that I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Why do we need any more testimony? We have heard it from his own lips.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the whole assembly rose and led him off to Pilate.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they began to accuse him, saying, “We have found this man subverting our nation. He opposes payment of taxes to Caesar and claims to be Messiah, a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Pilate asked Jesus, “Are you the king of the Jews?”
“You have said so,” Jesus replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pilate announced to the chief priests and the crowd, “I find no basis for a charge against this man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they insisted, “He stirs up the people all over Judea by his teaching. He started in Galilee and has come all the way here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On hearing this, Pilate asked if the man was a Galilean.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he learned that Jesus was under Herod’s jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod, who was also in Jerusalem at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Herod saw Jesus, he was greatly pleased, because for a long time he had been wanting to see him. From what he had heard about him, he hoped to see him perform a sign of some sort.
speaker: Narrator

text: He plied him with many questions, but Jesus gave him no answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief priests and the teachers of the law were standing there, vehemently accusing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Herod and his soldiers ridiculed and mocked him. Dressing him in an elegant robe, they sent him back to Pilate.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day Herod and Pilate became friends—before this they had been enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pilate called together the chief priests, the rulers and the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to them, “You brought me this man as one who was inciting the people to rebellion. I have examined him in your presence and have found no basis for your charges against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither has Herod, for he sent him back to us; as you can see, he has done nothing to deserve death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, I will punish him and then release him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the whole crowd shouted, “Away with this man! Release Barabbas to us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Barabbas had been thrown into prison for an insurrection in the city, and for murder.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Wanting to release Jesus, Pilate appealed to them again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they kept shouting, “Crucify him! Crucify him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the third time he spoke to them: “Why? What crime has this man committed? I have found in him no grounds for the death penalty. Therefore I will have him punished and then release him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But with loud shouts they insistently demanded that he be crucified, and their shouts prevailed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pilate decided to grant their demand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He released the man who had been thrown into prison for insurrection and murder, the one they asked for, and surrendered Jesus to their will.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the soldiers led him away, they seized Simon from Cyrene, who was on his way in from the country, and put the cross on him and made him carry it behind Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: A large number of people followed him, including women who mourned and wailed for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus turned and said to them, “Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for me; weep for yourselves and for your children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the time will come when you will say, ‘Blessed are the childless women, the wombs that never bore and the breasts that never nursed!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then
“‘they will say to the mountains, “Fall on us!”
    and to the hills, “Cover us!”’
speaker: Narrator

text: For if people do these things when the tree is green, what will happen when it is dry?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Two other men, both criminals, were also led out with him to be executed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the place called the Skull, they crucified him there, along with the criminals—one on his right, the other on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus said, “Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing.” And they divided up his clothes by casting lots.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people stood watching, and the rulers even sneered at him. They said, “He saved others; let him save himself if he is God’s Messiah, the Chosen One.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The soldiers also came up and mocked him. They offered him wine vinegar
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “If you are the king of the Jews, save yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a written notice above him, which read: this is the king of the jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the criminals who hung there hurled insults at him: “Aren’t you the Messiah? Save yourself and us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the other criminal rebuked him. “Don’t you fear God,” he said, “since you are under the same sentence?
speaker: Narrator

text: We are punished justly, for we are getting what our deeds deserve. But this man has done nothing wrong.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus answered him, “Truly I tell you, today you will be with me in paradise.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was now about noon, and darkness came over the whole land until three in the afternoon,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the sun stopped shining. And the curtain of the temple was torn in two.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus called out with a loud voice, “Father, into your hands I commit my spirit.” When he had said this, he breathed his last.
speaker: Narrator

text: The centurion, seeing what had happened, praised God and said, “Surely this was a righteous man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people who had gathered to witness this sight saw what took place, they beat their breasts and went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all those who knew him, including the women who had followed him from Galilee, stood at a distance, watching these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a man named Joseph, a member of the Council, a good and upright man,
speaker: Narrator

text: who had not consented to their decision and action. He came from the Judean town of Arimathea, and he himself was waiting for the kingdom of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Going to Pilate, he asked for Jesus’ body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took it down, wrapped it in linen cloth and placed it in a tomb cut in the rock, one in which no one had yet been laid.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was Preparation Day, and the Sabbath was about to begin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The women who had come with Jesus from Galilee followed Joseph and saw the tomb and how his body was laid in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went home and prepared spices and perfumes. But they rested on the Sabbath in obedience to the commandment.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the week, very early in the morning, the women took the spices they had prepared and went to the tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text: They found the stone rolled away from the tomb,
speaker: Narrator

text: but when they entered, they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were wondering about this, suddenly two men in clothes that gleamed like lightning stood beside them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In their fright the women bowed down with their faces to the ground, but the men said to them, “Why do you look for the living among the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: He is not here; he has risen! Remember how he told you, while he was still with you in Galilee:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘The Son of Man must be delivered over to the hands of sinners, be crucified and on the third day be raised again.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they remembered his words.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came back from the tomb, they told all these things to the Eleven and to all the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and the others with them who told this to the apostles.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not believe the women, because their words seemed to them like nonsense.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peter, however, got up and ran to the tomb. Bending over, he saw the strips of linen lying by themselves, and he went away, wondering to himself what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now that same day two of them were going to a village called Emmaus, about seven miles from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were talking with each other about everything that had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they talked and discussed these things with each other, Jesus himself came up and walked along with them;
speaker: Narrator

text: but they were kept from recognizing him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked them, “What are you discussing together as you walk along?”
They stood still, their faces downcast.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them, named Cleopas, asked him, “Are you the only one visiting Jerusalem who does not know the things that have happened there in these days?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What things?” he asked.
“About Jesus of Nazareth,” they replied. “He was a prophet, powerful in word and deed before God and all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief priests and our rulers handed him over to be sentenced to death, and they crucified him;
speaker: Narrator

text: but we had hoped that he was the one who was going to redeem Israel. And what is more, it is the third day since all this took place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition, some of our women amazed us. They went to the tomb early this morning
speaker: Narrator

text: but didn’t find his body. They came and told us that they had seen a vision of angels, who said he was alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then some of our companions went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said, but they did not see Jesus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “How foolish you are, and how slow to believe all that the prophets have spoken!
speaker: Narrator

text: Did not the Messiah have to suffer these things and then enter his glory?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And beginning with Moses and all the Prophets, he explained to them what was said in all the Scriptures concerning himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they approached the village to which they were going, Jesus continued on as if he were going farther.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they urged him strongly, “Stay with us, for it is nearly evening; the day is almost over.” So he went in to stay with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was at the table with them, he took bread, gave thanks, broke it and began to give it to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then their eyes were opened and they recognized him, and he disappeared from their sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked each other, “Were not our hearts burning within us while he talked with us on the road and opened the Scriptures to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up and returned at once to Jerusalem. There they found the Eleven and those with them, assembled together
speaker: Narrator

text: and saying, “It is true! The Lord has risen and has appeared to Simon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two told what had happened on the way, and how Jesus was recognized by them when he broke the bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were still talking about this, Jesus himself stood among them and said to them, “Peace be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were startled and frightened, thinking they saw a ghost.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Why are you troubled, and why do doubts rise in your minds?
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at my hands and my feet. It is I myself! Touch me and see; a ghost does not have flesh and bones, as you see I have.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had said this, he showed them his hands and feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while they still did not believe it because of joy and amazement, he asked them, “Do you have anything here to eat?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave him a piece of broiled fish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he took it and ate it in their presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “This is what I told you while I was still with you: Everything must be fulfilled that is written about me in the Law of Moses, the Prophets and the Psalms.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he opened their minds so they could understand the Scriptures.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “This is what is written: The Messiah will suffer and rise from the dead on the third day,
speaker: Narrator

text: and repentance for the forgiveness of sins will be preached in his name to all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are witnesses of these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to send you what my Father has promised; but stay in the city until you have been clothed with power from on high.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had led them out to the vicinity of Bethany, he lifted up his hands and blessed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was blessing them, he left them and was taken up into heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they worshiped him and returned to Jerusalem with great joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they stayed continually at the temple, praising God.
speaker: Narrator
